Award.AwardTitle: TC: EAGER: Binary-based Data Structure Revelation for Memory Forensics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Today's computer users often run programs for which they do not have the source code. In some cases, those programs are viruses or other malware, and it is desirable to understand how they work in order to prevent them from causing further damage or to track down the author. Part of the process of understanding the program (sometimes called "reverse engineering")is to understand how it stores data. This research develops a new technique for revealing the data structures in programs for which only the binary code is available called REWARDS -- Reverse Engeineering Work for Automatic Revelation of Data Structures. The tools developed by the research are evaluated against both benign and malicious programs.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US ZH-CN X-NONE Normal 0 false false false EN-US ZH-CN X-NONE Normal 0 false false false EN-US ZH-CN X-NONE Memory forensics, an important aspect of cyber forensics, involves analyzing memory images obtained from a victim or criminalÃ†s computer. The machine may be executing a close-source application or operating system, leaving its program data in the memory image at run time. As such, memory forensics entails two key challenges: (1) given a binary program without source code, how to infer the data structures – including their syntactic and semantic definitions – defined in the program and (2) given the inferred data structure definitions (e.g., process control blocks, IP addresses, browser cookies, contact lists, etc.), how to generate high-accuracy memory scanners to uncover instances of the corresponding data structures from a memory image. Intellectual Merit: This two-year (with a one-year no-cost extension) EAGER project is a pilot study on the above challenges in memory forensics. The proposed research is among the first to take a binary analysis-centric approach to (1) infer data structure definitions from a binary program; (2) define data structure signatures based on point-to relations among data structures; and (3) recognize data structure instances from incomplete memory images. More specifically, this project has led to a series of three main techniques: (1) REWARDS is a technique that takes a binary program as input and infers the data structure definitions in the program based on dynamic binary analysis. REWARDS leverages the public interface of system calls and library calls made in the program as data type resolution points and performs data flow tracking to transitively resolve data types at other memory locations and registers. (2) SigGraph is a technique that transforms the inferred data structure definitions to graph-based data structure signatures. Such signatures will then be used for brute-force scanning of memory images to recognize instances of the corresponding data structures. SigGraph leverages the "point-to" relations between data structures and computes data structure signatures that are mutually non-identical, hence achieving high accuracy of data structure recognition. (3) DIMSUM is a technique that further improves SigGraph by recognizing data structure instances in an incomplete set of physical memory pages without any memory mapping information. DIMSUM is based on probabilistic inference. Given a set of memory pages and the definition of a target data structure, DIMSUM will identify instances of the data structure in those memory pages with quantifiable confidence (i.e., probabilities). The suit of techniques above has been shown to be effective for both user-level and kernel-level data structures, complementing existing memory forensics techniques. Papers on these techniques have been published in the Network and Distributed Systems Security Symposium (2010, 2011, and 2012). Broader Impacts: Results from this research will empower cyber forensics analysts with advanced capability to uncover investigation leads and evidence from memory images captured at crime scenes. From 2010 to 2012, the PIs participated in the Northrop Grumman Cybersecurity Research Consortium (NGCRC), with Cyber Forensics being a focus area.
